intro: Richaeia gummiflua, commonly known as the gummed richaeia, is a rare and unique plant species native to specific regions of South America. It is characterized by its distinctive, gelatinous resinous substance that exudes from its stems and leaves, which has led to its common name. The plant belongs to the family Lecanoraceae and is a type of lichen, though it is sometimes classified as a composite organism due to its symbiotic relationship between algae and fungi. Its botanical features include a thallus structure that is typically crust-like or foliose, with a dark green to blackish coloration. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, Richaeia gummiflua is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
